answers.text:
The City of Goodyear is also in the process of a telephone replacement project, also in the next 12 - 18 months but never really considered bypassing the landline philosophy for many reasons; centralized\internal management, continuity of operations, consistency in numbers\extensions, voice mail, the hope of incorporating unified messaging\communications at some point and lastly, data management. I would be interested in hearing your list of pros and cons on the subject, perhaps we could communicate off line.
Regards,
Kathy Fernandez, KathyFernandez@goodyearaz.gov

answers.author: Phillip Smith-Hanes
answers.text:
We just went to a Voice over IP platform last fall.  Our provider said that one of the options (which we haven't instituted yet) was a mobile device (sort of the cell phone equivalent of a "dumb terminal" computer).  It would be useful for folks who need mobility but want to stay on the county's central phone system.  Another option that our system allows is call forwarding to outside numbers (including cell phones).

author: Pamela Muse
text:
Pitkin County, CO is interested in learning if there are other local governments who are shifting phone services from land lines to cell phones.  They are looking at a new phone system and wondering if current practices is overly duplicative?
We are looking at a new phone system in the next 18 month and wonder if our current practice is overly duplicative in many cases.
Thanks,
John Redmond
Pitkin County 
John.Redmond@co.pitkin.co.us
title: Cell Phone VS Land Lines
